title: It is absolutely necessary to create and integrate an extensive item shop tutorial for new players
body:
One of the things that I occasionely think about, is how much of a torture it is for new players to learn this game. I say to myself: how often would you find a player who can endure the learning process of this game, which takes an extremely long time, patience, and playing with so many smurfs? This is especially true for people who don't really have friends who can teach them everything quickly.

From a personal experience, what I find to be the roughest and most complex aspect to learn for new players is item builds. Sometimes, people reach level 30 without a clue of proper item builds, and that's why reaching level 30 is deceptively just the very first step for these new players who might think otherwise. This is why an extensive and thorough item tutorial for building each class and subclass of champions should be integrated with the game tutorial.

I am pretty confident that an item tutorial would be the most effective implementation to accelerate new player's learning process, and will greatly smoothen the learning curve of this game. In my opinion, it is neccessary, especially given the lack of tutorials in this game.

Even more radically: what about an "auto-buy" option for new Summoners?

LoL's got a really intense learning curve. It might be nice to have the game (by default, anyway) auto-buy items for the first five levels or whatever. Once they hit level 5, have it switch to regular shop mode, and pop up a message linking them to a shop tutorial.

It might sound totally crazy, but might there not be some sense in letting the newest players focus entirely on the game itself, before introducing the shop? It's not like most level 3 Summoners (smurfs aside; and they can disable the auto-buy feature) are going to know better than "click the recommended items" anyway.
or you could like look at guides made by fellow players ._.

> or you could like look at guides made by fellow players ._.

I'm not sure how effective that would be for a level 3 Summoner. The problem isn't that they don't know what to buy in an abstract strategic sense, it's that absolutely everything in the game is brand new to them.

I'm not at all convinced that an auto-buy feature is the right decision. I'm just putting it forward as a radical option to promote discussion and debate.

I don't consider myself stupid, but when I played my first game of Dawngate, their shop was absolutely the most confusing thing. I clicked the shop button, and it was full of icons leading to other icons, none of which I recognized. When I clicked on one of them, it rattled off the names of stats I'd never heard of, together with numbers for which I had no context. Sure, I could mouse over them for more information, but it was a lot to read and absorb in the middle of a match.

Even with a lot of LoL experience to analogize with, I was pretty much just clicking buttons.

Now, it's true, you can then go and read the wiki or whatnot, but that's still quite a lot of information to soak up, and most of it doesn't really make sense until you have some gameplay experience for context. ("Oh, she's killing tanks really well because she has Last Whisper. That's for penetrating % armor. That's better versus high-armor targets, whereas the flat ArPen is better for low-armor targets.")

It's all second nature to us now, but it's important to remember that we're talking about the experience of the very newest players.

When I started LoL, I didn't realize that "weapons" stacked. "Wait, why would I buy a sword? She's already got a bow. How do you switch weapons?"

I've had friends quit LoL in part because they found it really confusing and stressful being asked to make all these item decisions in the middle of a match, while they were already trying to understand the rest of the game. It's a *lot* of information at once. Remember, I'm talking about the very newest players here.

I'm thinking about the situation over all, and I think the best possible option would be to have an "Advanced Mode" button in the shop window, that way new players could use the simple mode that directs you with what item to buy next, which is pretty much what recommended items is, but even that gets confusing to rookies that don't know what is what or good for them at what point in the game. And the smurfs and advanced players could go on with their normal builds. 

And while this may not sound like it does anything to nerf the smurf persay, it makes it a more even playing field when the real new player has a decent item build order.

Yeah, maybe a halfway option, like some streamlined way to just buy the next item or component in the recommended items list.

After playing a lot of LoL, it almost seems absurd to me, but then I remember how confusing it was. I've definitely had friends tell me that the worst part of their new player experience was the shop.

However; if Riot came up with some kind of Helper or Tutor program where seasoned players are teamed with new players to help coach them by suggesting items, skill paths, and strategies, I think that would be the best way to help learn how to build items.

Right, so: I upvoted this and cannot agree enough, but there's something I wanted to touch on.

>This is why an extensive and thorough item tutorial for building each class and subclass of champions should be integrated with the game tutorial.

>integrated with the game tutorial

>game tutorial

My personal opinion is that the current tutorial system is hopelessly inadequate.  It's basically a five minute instructional video that shows you what turrets are and points at the Nexus; the tutorial covers nothing about deeper mechanics such as last hitting, zoning, teamfighting, communication, etc. 

I don't think that attempting to add a specific tutorial like itemization to the current system would be anywhere near as beneficial as overhauling the entire tutorial system, and it's very possible to create something that can be used by **almost everyone, regardless of skill level** rather than a single piece of content at the beginning that's never touched again.

---

The reason I bring this up is that items don't really make sense until you have a basic understanding of the game's mechanics.  Why should I buy armor against Riven but it's less effective against Irelia?  Why would I ever want a Sightstone, it gives bad stats.  When should I be building offensively as opposed to defensively?  Why do opponents have more items than me?  How do I get more money for items? Why did everyone just leave my lane and disappear to the bottom half of the map?

A tutorial about itemization without a strong backbone in general mechanics would fall on relatively deaf ears, I feel.

I'm still new to League and about to hit 30 for the first time, but during my learning process I really didn't need extraneous tutorials due to the fact I was willing to go outside of the game to find information about normal strategies. Such as effective builds, armor->apen->ad equations, and how to play certain champions to their inherit strengths and weaknesses. I'm by no means a veteran player yet, but the information available outside of the game is rather abundant (though that's inconvenient to more casual gamers).

I have to agree however, with how complex building a jungler may be now with the potential variance in viable builds per-champion, that breaking things down for new players would really help their early progression.

Playing as a first time pre-30 with a bunch of smurfs isn't pleasant, not due to the extra challenge associated with it (I like that, honestly, I learn faster under pressure), but the degradation and toxicity aimed toward you if you aren't performing up to 'standard' (standard being relevant to the team's average experience composition, which is usually far out of reach of 'newbie'-levels); moreover, it is bad enough to make new players not even bother continuing to play the game at the early stages. The problem rests on the learning stages requiring you to pretty much do said learning through trial and error exclusively, meaning you're going to be subject to harassment more than likely.
